titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. After walking an hour before Breakfast, and hearing Charles read after it, I attended the sale of Books, and made some purchases; on my return home I found letters from my dear mother, and brother, and one from his wife to mine— They were the most consolatory letters I had received from America these two years— Miss Frederica Bode and Mr Forbes, dined and passed the Evening with us untill ten— Captain Guedes sent me an excuse, on account of indisposition, and Miss Clementine de Bode, though invited did not come— Mr Smith also received a letter from his brother John at New-York.

2. I rose at dawn of day, before 5 O’Clock, and after reading and writing about two hours, walked another hour untill Breakfast time— I attended the sale of Books— While I was out, Mr Proud called, and told Mrs Adams that Mr Plummer and he together with Mr Gair, had now concluded to go next Tuesday, by the way of Finland as they had at first intended; and they wished me to obtain the Passports for them, for that day. Mr Harris sent me a London Courier of 18 Feby: containing the Debates in both houses of Parliament, the preceding day, on the Address to the Regent, approving the War against America, and promising their support to carry it on vigorously— Debates they can scarcely be called, for there is no opposition, to the Ministers— The only point upon which they are assailed is of having neglected waging the War with sufficient vigour hitherto. I walked again after dinner, and attempted to read in Cicero de Natura Deorum— I soon found myself too weary for attention and retired to bed.

3. Rose again between 4 and 5 O’Clock, and after reading and writing about three hours walked before Breakfast— Attended the sale of Books, at which the Grand Chambellan Narishkin made his appearance for about half an hour, and purchased two or three Books of splendid Editions— I sent Notes to Count Romanzoff and Count Löwenhielm, requesting Courier’s Passports for Mr Plummer and Mr Proud; received the Passport from Count Löwenhielm. Dined at Count Romanzoff’s, with a diplomatic company of a New description— A Count de la Feronais has arrived here from England,
and is going on to the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters— He comes upon a mission from Louis 18, and to him this dinner was apparently given. The Comte de Briou was there, an old Gentleman whom I had only seen before at Count Stedingk’s and at the Chevalier Bezerra’s— He has been a sort of Agent or Minister from Louis 18. but hitherto not recognized.— The Duke de Polignac was likewise one of the Company— I had dined there with him once before— I had some Conversation with Baron Blome, who is in great anxiety— He told me that the proposition for Peace made by Denmark to England had been rejected— The answer had been that they must treat at Stockholm, and on the basis of ceding Norway to Sweden— The Baron said this was a proposal to which it was impossible for Denmark to listen; but he did not know what his Government would do.— The news had just been received of the taking of Hamburg by the Russians— Young Gourieff had carried the keys of the City to Count Wittgenstein at Berlin— The whole City, 75000 people came out to meet the Russians in triumph, and such transports of joy were never before known— The mayor of the City Abendröth (a sinister name as Baron Budberg observed) they had thrown out of the windows— The king of Prussia has written a letter to Prince Kutuzoff, placing all his troops, under his command; submitting to him without restriction the whole management of the War, and requesting him to take the Prince Royal of Prussia for his Aid de Camp— This it was remarked was the only way in which any thing could be done to good purpose— I sat at table between Baron Budberg, and Mr Oubril, who reminded me that he had seen me at Berlin, where he was a Secretary to Baron Krudener, then the Russian Minister there— None of the English Embassy, Nor the Duke of Serra-Capriola, nor Count Maistre were there— But the Secretary and two Captains of the Spanish Legation were present— It was in truth a Bourbon dinner, and reminded me of the Resurrection of dry bones in the Prophet Ezekiel— Count Romanzoff was courteous as usual; but has more and more the appearance of declining influence— When I returned home, I found it useless to attempt reading— As we came down the stairs from the Counts Baron Campenhausen said “ma foi, si on faisoit tous les jours un diné comme cela, je crois qu’on mourroit au bout de deux ans—[”] I had not indulged myself so much as I do sometimes, but was not well disposed for study, and at my present usual hour of 9. finished the Evening.

4. I rose a little before six this morning, having had a good Night’s rest, and in good health and Spirits— Rigid temperance, steady and fatiguing exercise; a hard bed, and early hours, the recommendations of all the physicians and medical Books for sedentary men, do not entirely succeed in my experience of them— Dr. Buchan allows an occasional free participation of Entertainments, and I have hitherto followed his advice— I walked before Breakfast— Read prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the abuse of Conscience. The same that he published in Tristram Shandy— Wrote to my brother— Walked again after dinner; and then finished reading Olivet’s translation of Cicero de Natura Deorum— A large part of the third Dialogue is lost, which I very much regret— All the arguments of Cotta against the wisdom of Providence, in the structure of the human body, and in the usefulness of all created nature to man are lost. I should have wished to see the whole strength of the Academician as well as that of the Stoic— Cicero concludes by saying that Velleius (the Epicurean) thought Cotta’s argument the truest; but that he Cicero, thought that of Balbus the most probable— Ernesti says that this is mere dissimulation; for that Cotta delivers the real sentiments of Cicero— He draws the inference from the absurdity of the Stoic opinions, and the impossibility that Cicero should have believed them— There is one point, and that a very important one, in which Olivet the translator agrees with Cotta—which is that in matters of religion, we must not rely upon Reason, but take refuge in Authority. But to me this is impossible. I have no cause for peculiar Confidence in my own Judgment, but I cannot seat my faith upon the mere authority of other men— I began reading the Translation of the Books de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum, by Regnier Desmarais.

5. Charles is again affected with a violent Cold in the head, from which I suffer little less than himself. I rose before five; walked before Breakfast and after dinner, and employed the remainder of the day, untill 9 in the Evening at my ordinary occupations— Yet I wrote only one short letter, and finished reading the first and began upon the second Book de Finibus— A Disquisition upon the supreme Good— There are five Books—the first and second containing a Dialogue at Cicero’s villa at Cumae, between him—Torquatus and Triarius— Torquatus in the first Book sets forth the Epicurean Doctrine, which makes the summum bonum to consist in pleasure— It is refuted by Cicero in the second. Torquatus according to the fashion of the Epicureans applies great part of his discourse to the panegyric of the Graïus homo— But Cicero handles him very roughly, charging him with a total ignorance of physics, an absurd disdain of dialectics, a loose confused employment of terms, and a doctrine pernicious and detestable in morals— He says particularly that Epicurus held the Sun to be only three feet in diameter, and not larger than it appears to the human eye— And that he formally objected to all definitions of terms— A principle laid down by Torquatus is that the absence of pain is the most exquisite pleasure, and Cicero appears to labour with the utmost earnestness the contradiction of this maxim, which he says confounds the Nature of things— There is an ardour, partaking of Passion in all Cicero’s attacks upon Epicurus, but I believe it was well founded. The principles of that philosophy may properly be called the philosophy of Corruption, and it has always prevailed in company with the
the grossest licentiousness of morals, and the most infamous vices. Torquatus intimates that Cicero’s aversion to Epicurus arises from his having neglected the ornaments of language, and not written oratorically like Plato— But Cicero assures him that this is not the foundation of his objections— That Epicurus writes well enough to make himself understood, which is sufficient— That it his not his Style, but the substance of his doctrines that deserves Censure— I hope before long to ascertain what Lucretius has to say for Epicurus.

6. It was a great Russian festival—called the Annunciation to Mary— I rose before five— Walked before Breakfast and after dinner, and employed regularly the rest of the day— Mr Harris sent me some English Newspapers— Mr Plummer and Mr Lewis paid us visits in the Evening. I gave Mr Plummer his Passports and he left with me Mr Thorndike’s papers respecting the case of the Hector. He and Mr Proud think of going on Thursday, the day after to-morrow— I finished reading the second Book of Cicero de Finibus— His Dialogues are not so dramatic as those of Plato— He makes one Speaker set forth a philosophical dogma, and another refute it each in a continued discourse— Plato breaks his subjects up into conversations— Cicero’s method is more didactic, but Plato’s is more animated.

7. Our Company last Evening having brought me to later hours, than I have lately kept, I rose this morning little before six— There is so much regularity in the distribution of my time at present, that I have scarcely any thing to say to discriminate one day from another— After Charles’s morning lesson for which I allow two full hours, I passed the rest of this morning in reading over Mr Harris’s English Papers— In the Evening Mr Plummer and Mr Proud came and took leave of us— Their intention still is to go to-morrow. Countess Colombi, her two Sisters and Miss Pardo, (daughter of the late Spanish Minister) spent the Evening with the Ladies.

8. The last Evening having been continued to near Midnight. I rose this morning a quarter after six, but was prevented from walking by the rain— Mr Rea, Mr Plummer’s landlord came and invited me to his house at 2 O’Clock to a luncheon he was to give at his departure— I went accordingly after having attended at the sale of Books— Mr Harris, and several others of the Americans, residing here were there— I took leave again of Mr Plummer, Mr Proud and Mr Gair, who were going this afternoon— I had barely time to return home to dress, and went to dinner at Mr Laval’s— It was a dinner to the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff— The foreign Ministers were there, excepting Count Maistre who is unwell— The Duke de Polignac, and the Count de Briou were there; but Count de la Feronais left the City this day to go to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters— Messrs: Macdonald, Forbes, and Werry of the English Embassy were there— Also Mr Zea, and Mr Buys— The Marquis de Traversey and Captain Krudenstern— I sat at table, between Mr Buys, and a Mr Jakovleff, a relation of Count Romanzoff’s who has been Russian Minister at some of the States of Germany, and had much conversation with them both. Baron Blome told me the particulars of the failure of the Danish attempt to negotiate with England— He says they are here confident of succeeding with Austria. Madame de Laval told me she should go, for England in May— They have let their Country House to Mr Bardaxi the Spanish Minister. After returning home, I finished reading the third, and began the fourth Book de Finibus— I could however read little— Mrs: Adams has again been confined the whole day to her bed.— Mr Redwood called on me this morning to enquire again whether I had an answer from Mr Gourieff, on his business; but I had none.

9. The morning was fine and I walked before Breakfast— Attended the sale of Books— Dined at Count Romanzoff’s— Mrs: Adams being still confined to her bed could not go, and I took her excuses— The Duchess of Wirtemberg, the Princess Amelia of Baden, and the Duke of Oldenburg were there— The Duke said he should leave the City to-morrow— He is returning to be reinstated in his dominions. There were about thirty-five persons at table— I was seated between Miss Frederica Bode, and the Duke of Oldenburg’s Cavalier.— It being one of the fasting days, Miss Bode, who keeps rigorous lent found it difficult to make a dinner— The Duchess of Serra-Capriola was there—the first time I have seen her in company abroad. I asked Count Romanzoff, for an opportunity of conversing with him, and he appointed to morrow Morning at 11 O’Clock— After returning home I received a note from Countess Colombi, with two Notarial Certificates, which she requested me to authenticate— They were duplicates purporting that Don Francisco Colombi was appointed Guardian of the two infant children of the late General Pardo— I authenticated the Certificates, and sent them back with a note in answer to the Countess.

10. At eleven O’Clock this morning I called upon Count Romanzoff, according to his appointment— I told him that the object upon which I had desired now to speak with him; was scarcely of an official Nature, but arose from certain circumstances which had occurred here; and
and which I had thought it my duty to notice to him— That in the Russian, German, and French Gazettes of this City there had just been published translations of the English Prince Regent’s Declaration in Answer to the American Manifesto which accompanied the Declaration of War— That in the German Gazette, and I presumed therefore in the Russian of which that is only a translation, this Document was introduced by a sort of commendatory preface, apparently by the Editor of the Gazette, in which it was said to contain a true Statement of the Causes of the War between the United States and England— That as to the publication of the piece itself I had no disposition or right to complain of that, but the remark with which it had been introduced in the Russian and German Gazettes had given me some concern— It was my own persuasion that the English Declaration far from assigning the true Causes of the War, was an elaborate argument to assign a Cause totally false and unfounded— And what had most seriously affected me was that the Cause falsely assigned in the English Declaration, was calculated if believed by Russia to be true, to make Russia take an interest in the War, in favour of England, and against my Country— That the main effort of the Regent’s State Paper, was to inculcate the belief that the Causes assigned in the American Declaration were mere pretences, and that America had commenced the War under the influence, and in subserviency to the policy of France. This I affirmed to be absolutely false— I had officially communicated to him the Count the Views of the American Government with regard to France, at the time of the Declaration of War— It was not true that our quarrel with England had been produced by any operation of French influence— It was a question which we had to settle with England alone, and a question without settlement of which I did not believe it possible that Peace should be made— I added that although the English Answer to our Declaration had thus been published here at full length, the Declaration itself had not; and my principal object was to ask him, whether I could have translations of our Manifesto now published in the same papers which had given circulation to the Answer— The Count said, by all Means— That the introductory remark which I had noticed, as having been published with the English Regent’s Declaration was altogether wrong— That he did not know that it was in the paper; though he must acknowledge it was his fault that it was there— Supposing that the Declaration only was in the paper, and being overwhelmed with these newspapers, which they were perpetually bringing to him to read, he had stopp’d them from reading this document to him, and by that accident the remark had escaped his attention— That if I would send him translations of the American Declaration, they should be immediately published in the same Gazettes where the English Answer had appeared— That it was by no means the intention of Russia to take a side or constitute herself a judge in the War between the United States and England— That his own opinion was that I had truly stated the fact that the question was between America and England, altogether independent of any French influence— But from the same disposition not to take a part in this question, he wished me to send him the Translations of our Manifesto without any Commentary— I replied that this was my wish— I had abstained from every step that could bear even the construction of attempting to disturb the friendly relations between Russia and Britain— And all I asked was that the same measure should be meted out to us— I had indeed observed several indications of endeavours here to warp the public opinion here on the side of the English in their contest with us, but I had never much dreaded their effect, and had not thought them worthy of notice untill this occurrence— I assured him that I would send him the translations, as soon as I could have them made out— We then touched upon the subject of general European Politics, upon which I found the Count evidently dissatisfied with the present course of affairs— He expressed himself in terms but partially intelligible to me— He said it was now quite a fashion, to talk, as if there was but one object of attention in the affairs of Europe; and that one object was a single man— For his part he firmly believed that Providence would make the experiment of taking away the man, and leaving the world to see how they could settle their questions without him. As for himself, he was persuaded that if Providence had kept this little incident in reserve, after the first moment of rapturous joy should be over the world would be quite astonished to find itself as far from a state of harmony as ever, and with all its sources of discord, and additional new ones, to settle. I told the Count I had been much struck with the same remark of the general disposition to concentrate upon one individual man all the warfare and all the politics of the time— I believed with him that the man would be taken away and the questions would remain. But I consoled myself with reflecting upon the part which Russia was obviously called to take, in the present state of the world, and with the Confidence I had in the extent of her power, and the Moderation of her views— The Count replied that the Emperor was so accessible, by the goodness of his character, and then checked himself, without finishing the sentence.— It was absolutely necessary that there should be somebody to assume the office of regulator in this state of affairs— Somebody who should give the impulse to the system of futurity— He did not say it must be the Emperor of Russia, or speak as his Chancellor; but nothing could ensue but confusion, if as seemed now very much the tendency of things, the policy and the will of Europe was
was if he might so express himself, thrown into a Republic— Every one would have his project, and no two of them reconcileable with each other. The present tendency was to throw every thing into the popular channel— Every thing was to be done by popular movements— It was in substance a return of Jacobinism— Napoleon might be considered as the Don Quixote of Monarchy— He had to be sure overthrown many Monarchs; but he had done nothing against Monarchy— By affecting to make his person the only object of hostility, and by setting the populace at work to run him down, there would be a foundation laid for many future and formidable disorders— According to the principles of the antient diplomacy, it was a rule that every State must be negotiated with upon the basis of its interests and its powers— It would have been thought absurd to aim at obtaining from any one what he had not to give— For instance no one would have applied to an order of mendicant friars for a grant of money. Every one was to be dealt with according to his means, and that was to be required of him which he had to supply— Now it was to be all common concern, and all man and woman kind was to mingle in the deliberations. He asked me if I had seen Mr Schlegel’s pamphlet— I knew nothing even of the man— He said Mr Schlegel was a gentleman who had been here with Madame de Stael, and was still with her at Stockholm— A pamphlet had lately been published, ostensibly by him, though without his name— Madame de Stael he supposed was not the author of it; but he believed she had given it quelques coups de brosse— It professed in the title page to be printed at Hamburg, but had really been printed at Stockholm— He had received two copies of it from General Van Suchtelen (the Russian Minister in Sweden) and he would give me one of them; (which he did.) requesting only that I would not mention having received it from him— He said, with regard to its contents that he totally differed from the opinions it contained; and was much like Madame de Stael herself— She was a perfect sample of French women— It was impossible for a human mind to have more wit and vivacity; but such was the extreme mobility of her imagination, and such the inconsistency of her ideas, that in the result of every conversation you have with her it is the same thing as if you had been talking avec une folle.— I told the Count I had had the honour of two Conversations with her when she was here; and that in them she had given me the measure of her political system— It was personal resentment against Napoleon, because he had treated her ill— The Count laughed, and reminded me of the anecdote about Madame de Sevigné, Louis 14. and Bussy-Rabutin— I mentioned the new Proclamation of Louis 18 to the French People, and asked the Count, if it was known to have produced any effect in France— He said it was a good Proclamation; and he had no doubt would à la longue produce very considerable effects; though perhaps not immediately— It was certain that never since the Commencement of the French Revolution, had there been so general a removal of all the obstacles to the return of the Bourbons as there was at present; and he had long been of opinion that it would end sooner or later in their restoration— He had often said, and yet believed it would finally come to the king of the Almanac Royal— That is, he would not say that Louis 18 would be restored; or his brother the Comte d’Artois— He would not promise that the Duke d’Angoulême, or even that the Duke de Berri would ever come to the throne— It was impossible to ascertain the time when, or the individual in whom the restoration would be accomplished; but the Crown would eventually fall upon the lawful head, just as the succession would be arranged in the Almanack.— [“]There is yet however much to struggle through,[”] added the Count, [“]and even now, our political successes, will tend much to strengthen and consolidate his power internally.— France could have had nothing to fear directly from Russia— Even had Russia harboured hatred against France, which she does not, she is too distant; she can have no purposes of encroachment upon France. The nation therefore could feel but a feeble interest in a War against Russia— But now, on one side (Prussia) we have had a complete political success— We may have success equally complete on the other part. (Austria.) France will be thus put on the defensive, and must contend for her own territories— This no doubt will give new energy to her exertions, and will interest the Nation more in him whose cause will be thus identified with their own. We must wait to know the results”— On leaving the Count I called at Mr Harris’s, to enquire if he could tell me of persons who could make good French, Russian and German Translations of our Manifesto’s.— He named a person for the French, and said he would obtain information with regard to the others— I attended at the sale of Books, and bought several— Mr Harris spent the Evening with us.

11. Rose just at six, and walked before Breakfast— Read prayers for the Sunday before Easter, and Sterne’s Sermon, upon the temporal advantages of religion— It is in a style altogether grave and temperate, without any attempt to move the passions either pathetic or ludicrous. It is also a regular composition, suitably divided, and in which the arguments all have an obvious connection with the text— After dinner I walked on both the quay’s, from the lower ship-yard to the marble Palace— The river was breaking up, and there was a crowd of people at the Bridge waiting to see it removed, for which the Police-men were making preparations— I did not wait however to see it go— It was taken away about ten in the Evening— It has not broken up before, so early in the season since the
year 1803 and in the last ninety-five years not more than nine or ten times. The earliness of the Spring has been proportioned to the severity of the Winter— After I came home I finished reading the fourth Book of Cicero de Finibus— It is the refutation in his own name, of the Stoic doctrine on this question which had been set forth by Cato in the preceding Book— He insists that the opinion of the Stoics was the same as that of the Academy, in substance, and that they had only introduced some unnecessary new terms— Cato pretends that there was a great difference between them not only of words but of things— Cicero as might be expected has the best of the argument— There is some subtlety and even some obscurity in their reasoning on both sides, which is noticed by Cicero— He tells Cato, that he will not attack his philosophy as he had done in the Oration for Murena; for that he was then speaking to ignorant people, and adapted his discourse to their Understandings— On the whole it appears that the difference between the Stoics and the Academics on the nature of good and evil were mere disputes upon words— The Stoics held that the terms Good and Evil had reference solely and exclusively to the condition of the Soul and none to that of the body— That nothing was good but what was honest, and nothing evil but the dishonest. That sickness, poverty, loss of friends, children, and life were no Evils, and that in bodily pleasure, riches, honours, and every thing except Virtue there was nothing that deserved to be called good— They admitted however that all these things were such that wise men would prefer the latter to the former— The academicians allowed that the honest was incomparably the greatest of Good things and the dishonest the greatest of Evils— But that the Body was the subject of good and evil as well as the soul, because man was a being compounded of body and Soul— The doctrine of the Academy seems to me the most correct, and yet that of the Stoics had a tendency to sublimer Virtue, and more heroic action.

12. My eldest Son, George’s birth-day— May God Almighty bless him and his brothers, and grant them life and health, and virtue and make them useful citizens and men in their generation— I received notice this morning from the Grand-master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin, that at half past twelve O’Clock, there would be at the Imperial Chapel a Te Deum for the taking of Hamburg, and of the fortress of Lankoran in Persia. I went with Mr Smith a very few minutes later than the time fixed, and found the Empresses already in the Chapel— They usually make us wait at least an hour and a half— There was no Mass; and I entered the chapel just as the ad interim Minister of War, General Wiasmitinoff was beginning to read the official Accounts of the Events for which the ceremony had been ordered— It was finished before two O’Clock— Baron Blome came in immediately after me, and Count Löwenhielm some time later— When I came home I wrote untill dinner time. Mr Harris had called upon me, and taken two copies of the Documents which I wanted to get translated— The abbé Manguin has undertaken to get the three translations, Russian, German and French all made— Captain Bates also paid me a visit, with Mr Theodore Meyer, a native of Germany, and a Citizen of the United States, just arrived from Riga— I read the pamphlet given me by Count Romanzoff, in which I imagine Mr Schlegel had very little hand— That of Madame de Stael is betrayed in every line. Although the Count in strong terms disclaimed his concurrence in the opinions it contains, I much fear they will prevail in the policy both of Sweden and of Russia— The pamphlet is a perfect picture of Madame de Stael’s mind, and strongly exemplifies the remarks which the Count made to me about her— He told me that when she was here she had taken entire possession of poor Admiral Bentinck— But he thought Lord Cathcart had been a little shy of her— I had remarked the same. I closed this Evening by reading the fifth and last Book of Cicero de Finibus, translated by Regnier Desmarais— It is a dialogue of which the scene is laid at Athens in the Academy, between Cicero, his brother Quintus, his cousin or nephew Lucius, then a Student at Athens, Atticus, and Marcus Piso— This last is the principal Speaker, and sets forth for the instruction of young Lucius Cicero, the whole doctrine of the antient Academy concerning Good and Evil— They defined good, to be that which is conformable to nature, and evil, that which is contrary to it— These three dialogues have come to us entire I intend to read them again in the Original. Charles measures 3 f. 6 1/4 inches.

13. Mr Norman called on me this morning, and informed me that he expected to go in about ten days, at which time he wished me to apply for a Courier’s Passport for him; I had promised Mr Harris that I would— Miss Frederica Bode dined with us.— It being the first day of the Month according to the Russian Style, I was occupied part of the day with domestic concerns— After my Evening walk I read Olivet’s translation of Cicero’s first Tusculan disputation— There are five—On Death—Pain—Affliction—the Passions and Virtue— The first second and fourth are translated by Olivet; the third and fifth by Bouhier— They are addressed to Brutus, and avowedly in the Socratic form of Dialogue— He supposes a conference at Tusculum between himself and a man of straw whom he is to refute and convince— It is not an alternate discussion like the Books on Good and Evil, where each side supports its doctrine with all its arguments; but a mere statement of positions by one party, with an elaborate argument by the other— Thus in the first Tusculan, after an introduction exposing the plan of the work, addressed to Brutus, he makes his interlocutor begin thus “I think death an evil.” Upon which Cicero assumes to prove the contrary—
He draws his principal reasoning from the immortality of the Soul, which he accordingly labours to prove, and does prove as far as it can be shewn by the light of Nature— The drift of the discourse very strongly resembles that of Socrates in the Phaedo, from which he makes several long quotations— There appears some superfluous exertion to shew that Death is not an Evil, to the Dead, the contrary being too absurd to be affirmed by any body accustomed to philosophical discussion. The natural horror of Death will always be more than a match for Philosophy— It is perhaps impossible to prove Death an Evil; but it is certainly impossible to feel that it is not.

14. The frost was so sharp last Night, that the Canals were all frozen over again, and I found the walking this morning like mid-winter. There was a large fall of Snow which continued the greatest part of the day. I attended at the Auction, and afterwards called at the house with Charles, and took home in the Carriage about half the Books, and the music that I have purchased. I wrote very little and did not walk after dinner— I read the second Tusculan, translated by the Abbé d’Olivet— It is upon pain; and the argument urges, that pain is to be despised— Cicero’s interlocutor who had been convinced the day before that death was not an evil, begins this Conference by asserting that pain is the greatest of all evils— Cicero easily brings him to acknowledge that it is not so great an evil as shame; and after having subdued the terror of Death, that of pain could not be a very difficult conquest—the Conference is therefore not more than half as long as the first.

15. I took Charles out to walk with me this morning, and we went round through the Street of the Maltese Palace, where the display of artificial flowers is making previous to Palm-Sunday— After Breakfast I attended again at the auction of Books— Count Maistre called to pay me a visit while I was out— After dinner I walked again; and although Charles employed me part of the Evening, I read the third Tusculan translated by Bouhier— It is on Sorrow, and the means of mitigating it— It contains a number of verbal discussions and definitions of terms which Bouhier omits from his translation, as not susceptible of being expressed in another language— But all Cicero’s philosophical treatises abound in such disquisitions, and he is continually remarking upon the necessity he is under of using new words which he is of course obliged to define— The latin language had no word to express the idea of the Passions— Cicero therefore calls them perturbations of the mind; and two entire chapters in which this topic is discussed are omitted by Bouhier— In this Book Cicero renews his attack upon Epicurus, and replies to the assertion of some Epicureans that he Cicero had not rightly understood the principles of that Sect— He shews that in spite of all subterfuge and equivocation sensual pleasure is the Supreme Good of Epicurus, and he does not spare the doctrine.

16. Charles walked with me this morning, and again in the Evening— I attended the Auction, without effect. Received letters from Mr Speyer, at Stockholm, and from Mr Fosdick at Gothenburg—the last was under cover to Mr Fisher and had been opened— In the Evening I read the fourth Tusculan translated by d’Olivet— It is upon the Passions, or mental perturbations, which he distributes into four general kinds—Lust and Joy—Grief and Fear— He adopts this classification from the Stoics, and in general approves the Stoic doctrine concerning the Passions, which he contends are to be totally subdued.— He severely censures the opinion of the peripatetics, that the Passions were necessary and were only to be regulated— He says that to approve moderate Passions, is to approve moderate injustice, moderate cowardice, moderate intemperance— That all indulgence of the Passions is vicious and that they must be inflexibly extirpated— He candidly admits that when he wrote his Consolation, on the Death of his daughter he was not wise; but he insists that in all his proceedings during his Consulship, against Catiline, he was never one moment under the influence of anger— At the same time he insinuates that as an Orator, he affected anger, for the purpose of rousing that of his hearers, and he adds that he does not chuse to speak more clearly, lest he should reveal one of the mysteries of the Art.

17. Mr Lewis sent me a letter he received last Evening from Gothenburg with news from America to 23 February— Further disasters by land, and successes upon the Sea— “In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God also hath set the one over against the other to the end that man should [find nothing after him—[instead of which, read “not know what is to come.”] Ecclesiastes VII.14. so it is translated in Luther’s German Bible— 1000 more men with a General Winchester killed or taken in Canada, and the Java Frigate, sunk by the Constitution Captain Bainbridge— I went with Charles to Grabit’s and brought home the remainder of the articles I had purchased at the sale, among which was a Loto-Box which chiefly excited his curiosity— I walked alone after dinner and on returning home read the fifth Tusculan, translated by Bouhier; the subject is Virtue—the argument that it is sufficient for the happiness of Man—and it concludes this admirable Work— Nothing can stand a comparison with the genuine doctrines of Christianity, in their application to the pursuit of happiness, but setting them aside this Socratic and Ciceronian Moral Philosophy, is the most exalted system of human conduct that ever was presented to the world— Its tenets were beyond the ordinary level of human infirmity, and so are those of Christianity— It made the essence of Virtue to consist
in self-subjugation, and so does Christianity— It gave out a theory of perfection to the aim of man, and made the endeavour to attain it his duty— So does Christianity— The perfect example indeed was not given, as by Christ; not even by Socrates. Yet he and Cicero, and many of the sectaries of this philosophy did attain an eminence of practical Virtue highly laudable— In this last Book Cicero indulges his oratorical manner of discourse freely, and with great eloquence— He mentions the practice of the women of India of being burnt, upon the Death of their husbands— This is one of the strongest proofs how the horror of death can be overcome, even by the female sex. I marvel nevertheless that such a Custom should have subsisted so long; for it is yet in full vigour notwithstanding all the efforts of the Christians to obtain its abolition— In this Book Cicero relates his discovery of the tomb of Archimedes near Syracuse, when he was Quaestor in Sicily— He also tells the story of Pythias and Damon— Mr Harris called on me this morning, to speak of the Translations which he is procuring for me, and which are not finished— We closed the Evening with a game of Loto.

18. It is Easter-Sunday in the Roman Catholic, Lutheran and Anglican Churches; and Palm-Sunday here— The morning was fine, and I took Charles out to walk with me— We went into the Roman Catholic Church, where we saw a shrubbery of palm-branches, which were to receive benediction at 11. O’Clock— I read prayers for Easter-Sunday, and Sterne’s Sermon upon having our Conversation in Heaven— A serious and eloquent discourse— The weather changed to Snow the latter part of the day, and I kept house— In the Evening I read several Chapters of Paley’s Natural Theology— He states his argument clearly, by the similitude of a watch, and his reasoning to prove contrivance in the construction of the eye and the ear is ingenious, learned, and impressive— I wanted to consult Ray and Derham, the titles of whose works shew that they took the same basis of argument, but I have not the books at hand— There is great variety and minuteness of knowledge displayed in this work— Of natural History and comparative Anatomy in the descriptions of the eye and ear, and other parts of organized bodies— Of mechanics in the description of the watch— Of Metaphysics, in the statement of the atheistic arguments— I believe there is not much atheism in the World— But the illustration of the watch, and the Steam-engine cannot account for Creation—it explains only the intelligence of organization—the materials of which the machine is composed exist independent of the workman— Mere intelligence is not competent to create— The watch is only combination; The creative power is beyond the reach of my Understanding— I believe it, as revealed in Scripture, and I infer it from the intelligence and power manifested in the mechanism of the Universe— But I cannot embrace the idea with any distinctness, and I see no attempt by Paley to prove it— Mr Smith dined at Mr Krehmer’s— Charles interrupted much my reading in the Evening, and my sluggish drowsiness benumbed my application— I finished the Evening at 9 O’Clock.

19. I attended the auction, but there were no books sold, and I made no purchases— My Cook, Quinzard gave me notice that he should leave me at the end of this Month— A serious loss; for he is one of the best, and the most honest Cooks that I ever knew— In this Country, and I believe in all others, a good Servant is a treasure, seldom to be found, and still more rarely to be long possessed— In America a good Servant can always rise from his station— Here he can always find a better place— Quinzard is the second I have thus lost— I took my Morning and Evening walks alone, and read further in Paley’s Natural Theology.— There is so much of his anatomy that it becomes a little tedious— He expatiates on the proofs of Contrivance in the mechanism of every part of the human body— The bones, Sinews, Muscles, Cartilages, Arteries, Veins, Bowels and their Contents— It is heaping proof upon proof more than is necessary to a mind already convinced. He quotes Derham once, and Keil, Cheselden, Hunter, Home, the Philosophical Transactions, and others— He writes with as little technical language as possible; but without plates, and without inspection, description can never convey distinct ideas. We are indeed fearfully and wonderfully made, and manifest the work of a maker, in whose hands matter is an instrument obedient to the Will. Human intelligence must take matter as it finds it; but the action of the Creator is as astonishing, perhaps more so, in the modifications of matter, as in the mechanism of organized bodies— Upon this however Paley touches very lightly, because he says it is chemistry, and he lays the stress of his argument upon mechanism— At the close of the Evening we played Loto.

20. Captain Norman called upon me this morning to tell me that he had postponed his departure untill the next week, and that he might probably go by the way of Hamburg, instead of passing through Sweden— Mr Harris came in the Evening, and mentioned that Mr Norman had concluded to go with a Mr Gosler, a German Merchant, to Hamburg, if I could insert Mr Gosler’s name in the application
for a Courier’s Passport; I had some hesitation about this; Mr Gosler not being an American; and the Courier’s Passport bearing an exemption from the usual regulations under which other travellers are restricted— I promised Mr Harris to give a definitive answer in two or three days— I attended the sale, and as often happens passed over what I went for and purchased what I had not intended— The sale finishes to-morrow— Mrs Adams is again quite unwell— I walked after dinner, and on returning read in Paley’s Natural Theology— I was soon obliged to lay aside the Book, overpowered with drowsiness, and was just retiring to bed, when Mr Harris came in— He passed an hour with us: and upon going to bed I found my drowsiness not only vanished, but I had an extremely restless and almost sleepless Night. [symbols]

21. The loss of rest in the Night as usual made me rise later this morning, and weakened my power of application through the day— I only walked before Breakfast; the day and Evening weather, Snow and rain having confined me to the house— A Frenchman named Jaquet, came and offered me his services as Cook— He is to come again with his Certificates— Doctor Galloway called and sat with me an hour— His conversation is agreeable and very much diversified. I like it better than his professional advice to myself—for he recommends good-living, and generous wines, to which the lust of the flesh is already too prone, and in which I indulge myself more than enough— My own opinion and experience both prescribe a curb to the appetite and not a spur— I distrust therefore the advice which recommends pampering— I continued reading in Paley’s Natural Theology this Evening; but was forced to quit the Book very soon. It spins out the argument of intelligence, in the construction of animal bodies, untill it becomes tiresome— His chapters of comparative Anatomy, peculiar organizations, prospective contrivances, and relations, contain a multitude of facts in Natural History; but as evidence his description of the eye is abundantly sufficient, and all the rest is cumulation.— Mr Forbes was here the latter part of the Evening.

22. Captain Norman called upon me this morning, and renewed his request to have the name of Mr Gosler inserted in his Passport. He mentioned that Mr Gosler had applied for an ordinary Passport which he expected to receive this week— I told Mr Norman that my only scruple arose from the apprehension that it might be considered by the Government here as interfering with their regulations of Police— But that if he would bring me Mr Gosler’s Passport when he receives it, I would then unless some other objection should occur, ask to have his name inserted in the Courier’s Pass.— At 4 in the afternoon I went with Charles to the Roman Catholic Church, and heard the service which they call Tenebres. Much of the day was employed in reading English Newspapers sent me by Mr Harris— I lost my Evening walk, and read only a few pages in Paley’s Natural Theology— Finished with Loto.

23. Good Friday, according to the Calendar of the Greek Church, and it is observed as such by all the other Churches here which observe it at-all— I went with Charles to the Roman Catholic Church, and saw the latter part of the same Ceremonies I had seen two years ago, on the same occasion (v. p. 233) The Sermon was preached by the same person, and as far as I can recollect, was identically the same Sermon. Mr Smith and I dined at Mr Harris’s— Mr Laval, Mr Lewis and Mr Slade were the only other company— I had after dinner much conversation with Mr Laval— He says that the English influence has very much declined here, within these four Months; but I believe he takes his wishes for the facts— After I came home we played Loto—without Mrs Smith, who is confined to her chamber— This day Charles finished reading the New Testament— The ice from lake Ladoga first appeared this day.

24. Charles walked with me this morning— They had already begun to put up the summer bridges, but were obliged to desist and remove the boats back to the river side, to allow the passage of the ice which continued all this day— At eight in the Evening I took Charles to the Roman Catholic Church to see the ceremony by which they represent the resurrection of Christ— The crowd of people was excessive; and the heat almost stifling. The Priests went in procession to the chapel where the scenery was exhibited—chanted part of the service there—then returned with the image of the body under a Canopy of crimson velvet—performed the rest of the service before the main altar; and with accompaniment of the organ, and of voices in the organ-loft after which they took away the image to the left-hand Chapel— The ceremony was about an hour long— We were at home again shortly after nine O’Clock— Mrs Smith was still confined to her chamber.— Charles began to read the Old Testament— Two Chapters with the Corresponding Explanations of the Prints in the French History of the Old and New Testament.— I received from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, notice for a Court, on Monday at Noon.

25. Easter-day, by the Greek Calendar— Excepting my solitary morning and Evening walks, I passed the day at home— I rose before five O’Clock, and about 7 we had an alarm of fire in the house— I was roused by a tumultuous noise in the Entry, and on going to enquire the cause of it, found a dozen of the Police Men, bursting open with a Crow-Bar the door to our garret— The washerwoman had the key and was gone out to Church— They broke open the door, and knocked out several bricks in a chimney, which passes through the garret
and they poured Water down the hole thus made to extinguish the fire— It had been kindled in the kitchen of a Taylor who inhabits the floor under ours; his apartment was considerably damaged by the fire, which was however very soon extinguished— We had the customary presents of eggs from the servants in the family, and the usual visiting Cards from multitudes of persons; most of whom we never see; nor hear of at any other time— Mr Harris paid me a Morning visit. I read prayers for the first Sunday after Easter, and Sterne’s Sermon entitled Description of the World— A discourse altogether serious; preached as appears by two passages in it during lent, and more in the common style, than any other in this Collection— I likewise read several Chapters of Paley’s Natural Theology— He pursues the argument of intelligence inferred from mechanism, through insects, Plants, the Elements, and Astronomy. The Chapters on the Personality, and the Unity of the Deity are not satisfactory to my Mind— I know not precisely what he means by personality, as applied to God— Personality applied to the human species is the composition of body and soul in every separate individual— It includes necessarily extension, which seems altogether incompatible with omnipresence— The personality of incorporeal Spirit is above my comprehension, and Dr Paley has not explained it to me— The Scriptures tell me that God made man after his own image, and constantly represent him, as operating in the concerns of mankind under a human form— This is easily conceived and in this sense I can conceive of the three persons of the Trinity— But it does not shew me that the number of Persons must be limited to three— Divine power may assume forms discernible to human sense, infinitely various; but otherwise I can form no distinct idea of the personality of an infinite Spirit— Dr Paley alledges only the uniformity of plan in the Universe to prove the Unity of God— But are there not other proofs equally conclusive, or more so— Is it absolutely necessary that there should be unity of agency wherever there is unity of plan?— I think not— But if the visible creation demonstrates infinite power—omnipotence, and omnipresence, it excludes unquestionably all plurality of omnipotent, omnipresent and all-intelligent beings— Two co-existent omnipotences appear to imply a confusion of terms.

26. The second of the Easter-Holidays. I went soon after twelve at Noon to the Winter Palace and attended at the Court held by the Empresses. Mr Smith did not go, his wife being confined with the scarlet fever— This disease is considered as highly infectious, and it is an etiquette that a person having intercourse with one affected by it must not go to Court. I went because I have not seen Mrs Smith, nor been in her chamber since she was seized with the complaint— The Court itself was like all others, excepting that the foreign Ministers received notice that they would have permission to kiss the hands of the two Empresses, which we all accordingly did— Mr Narishkin said that several of the foreign Ministers had expressed a desire to be admitted to that honour in consequence of which it was granted— The Court were all in very high spirits at the news of a victory gained by Count Wittgenstein over the Vice-Roy of Italy, near Magdeburg; of which a Bulletin was in Circulation— Baron Blome told me that his Government had sent Count Jochim Bernstorff a brother of the late Minister of foreign Affairs to London, but it was not yet certain what would be his reception— The Danish Government had recalled all their privateers, and ceased hostilities at the mouth of the Elbe— The British had done the same there, but not as a general measure— The Emperor Alexander had sent Prince Dolgoruki to Copenhagen with a letter to the King; who had sent his answer to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, by a young Count Moltke, who had been Danish Minister in Sweden— Mr Forbes of the English Embassy told me he was about returning to England— Mr Macdonald does the same, and Mr Werry follows the Ambassador to Head-Quarters— On returning home I found letters from Stockholm, Gothenburg and London; with slips from the newspapers containing information from America, to 24 February— Mr Harris afterwards sent me a letter he had received from Mr Speyer, with other and like extracts— Mr Lewis and Mr J. W. Smith, and afterwards Mr Slade paid us visits in the Evening— They also had similar news.— I walked morning and Evening— The day was very fine; but the river continues full of ice floating down from lake Ladoga. Charles has again a severe Cold— I read a few pages only in Paley’s Natural Theology.

27. At eleven this morning I went with Mr Smith to the Kazan Church and attended the Te Deum preceded by a Mass. The two ceremonies together employ three full hours— The Empresses, the two Grand Dukes, and the Grand Duchess Ann performed their Adorations at the miraculous image of the Virgin as usual—complete prostration— Ventre a terre, as Mr Laval expressed it. Count Löwenhielm was much occupied in making the Chevalier Bardaxi Azara the Spanish Minister lose the first place in the arrangement of the corps Diplomatique— The Chevalier as the Count observed, always affects to take the first place; and thereby said the Count shews a pretension
which I do not admit; I have spoken about it to the Duke of Serra-Capriola, because I had observed he always gives place to the Chevalier Bardaxi; and I told him that out of politeness and personal respect to him I should always very cheerfully give him precedence, and I would do the same to any other of my Colleagues— But as a pretension I could not allow it in any one of them— The Duke answered that he was instructed to yield precedence to the Spanish Minister, as representing the eldest Prince of the House of Bourbon— But I have no such Instructions, and Mr Bardaxi knows, that the rule established here is the alternative— Mr Bardaxi did not come untill after the Ceremony had begun— Count Löwenhielm’s effort was that the ranks should be kept so close that Mr Bardaxi should not be able to take the first place; but might be obliged to take the last— He succeeded only in part. Mr Bardaxi came, and attempted to get up to the top—this he could not effect, and finally found a passage at the third place, below the Duke and Baron Blome, and next above Count Maistre— I was between him and Count Löwenhielm. Mr Zea however who has manifested the same pretension of priming was now obliged to take the lowest place— These pretensions are troublesome things, and continually recurring— When the French set of Ministers were here, Baron Blome always made a point of getting his place next to the Ambassador, untill Count St: Julien was formally accredited, and afterwards next to him— Count St: Julien as the Austrian Minister, and a sort of an apology for an Ambassador, had peculiar distinctions shewn him, by the Emperor’s command; not without giving offence to the other Ministers— But he assumed and was allowed always to take the place next to the Ambassador— Blome’s pretensions were not then formally opposed, although they were particularly noticed, and contested by all the other Ministers— But since the change of politics at this Court Blome has not ventured to push his way before others, and has often been at the lowest place— When I first came here Mr Maisonneuve told me that the rule established here was the Pell-Mell—but that sometimes Ministers, and more commonly Ambassadors would not submit to the rule— The only reason why Count Stedingk and Count St: Julien had not the formal character of Ambassadors was to avoid contesting the precedence with the French Ambassador— In all these controversies I have endeavoured to consider it as an affair in which I as an American Minister had no concern— And that my only principle is to dispute upon precedence with nobody— After returning home I was engaged with newspapers untill dinner time— Walked in the Evening, and read a few pages in Paley’s Natural Theology— Charles omitted his reading this day.

28. Captain Norman called upon me this morning, and brought with him Mr Gossler’s Passport; upon which I consented to insert his name in the application for a Courier’s Pass for Mr Norman— He said they expected to be ready to go next Sunday, and wished to have the Passport ready for that day. I went with Charles and saw two of the Shows at the Gachellies— There were Puppet-shows at both. Punch and his wife, and the Doctor and the Captain and the Devil— Chinese Shadows, very bad— Slight of hand tricks, tumblers, and one slack-rope dancer, all equally wretched; the same that we have seen four or five times before— I walked after dinner, and finished the perusal of Paley’s Natural Theology— His argument points not to a Creator, but only to a fabricator mundi, and he professedly views its main pillar in Anatomy—the mechanism of the human body— There is acuteness and extensive combination of ideas in much of his reasoning, and his style is clear, neat, and popular— Sometimes elegant, and rarely eloquent— Never highly animated, but generally mild and persuasive.

29. I went again with Charles and saw two more of the exhibitions at the Gachellies—the first was the Chinese Shadows and Arabian fire, and the second Rope-dancing, on the slack-rope and tumbling; together with a man one of whose legs and feet were deformed—shaped like an arm and foot— He used the foot as a third hand— Ate, drank and played on the violin with it— And by attaching one cymbal to the side of his other leg, he played with two pair of cymbals at once— These two sets of performers were better than those we had seen yesterday and I do not recollect to have seen the last of them before— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a company of about 35 persons— Russian Officers and the foreign Ministers. There was much news, though none official. The taking of Thorn is known by a letter from the Duke of Oldenburg to the Empress Mother— Count Löwenhielm told me he had the protest of the 34 Members of Congress, in the Minority, against the War, and promised to send it to me— He spoke of it in terms of high approbation— Baron Blome next to whom I sat at dinner appeared to have recovered his Spirits again, and has become as warm an adversary to Bonaparte, as any man I see— He told me that he had seen his speech on closing the Session of the Legislative Assembly—in which not one word was said of the defection of Prussia— But he said he should very soon go in person and place himself at the head of his army— I asked where his army was— Blome said he did not know. He had also said in the speech that the Department of the Mouths of the Elbe had been offered to Denmark, as an indemnity for Norway—(meaning I suppose, offered by England and Russia)— I said that part of Hanover was in that Department— Oh! said Blome—it is only he says so, and what he says deserves no credit— In this case it is only partly true— Partly true it therefore is— The Hanseatic Cities are not likely to be long lived— I walked in the Evening, and we afterwards played at Loto.

30. In my morning walk I was thoroughly soaked by a heavy shower of rain.— It was then warm; but grew colder the whole day, and snowed in the Evening— I went with Charles, and saw two more of the Exhibitions at the Gachellies— Automaton figures, and Puppets, with a Battle and a shipwreck— The same we had seen last year.— I omitted my Evening walk, and read several Chapters of Malthus’s Essay on the principle of Population, a Book that I have borrowed of Mr Harris.

Day— As the last Month. I have risen more constantly, about 5 O’Clock— Often half an hour earlier; and through the Month, not once later than 6. The distribution of my time has suffered no change in the Month, but it is now scarcely dark at 9 in the Evening, and I must take a later hour for going to bed— Charles has made no perceptible progress in his reading; but has finished the New and begun upon the old Testament— The Easter week, and other Circumstances have sometimes interrupted his lessons and his health has continued infirm. I conclude with remarking that notwithstanding my early hours, and continual employment, I do little more than Nothing at-all.
